description: From Middle English [Term?], borrowed from Latin suspīciō, suspīciōnem, from suspicere, from sub- (“up to”) with specere (“to look at”). Perhaps partly through the influence of Old French sospeçon (or rather the Anglo-Norman form suspecioun). Equivalent to suspect +‎ -ion.

entries.meaning: The act of suspecting something or someone, especially of something wrong.

examples: In former days every tavern of repute kept such a room for its own select circle, a club, or society, of habitués, who met every evening, for a pipe and a cheerful glass. […] Strangers might enter the room, but they were made to feel that they were there on sufferance: they were received with distance and suspicion.

entries.meaning: The imagining of something without evidence.

verbs.description: suspicion (third-person singular simple present suspicions, present participle suspicioning, simple past and past participle suspicioned)

entries.meaning: (nonstandard, dialect) To suspect; to have suspicions.
examples: Mulvaney continued— "Whin I was full awake the palanquin was set down in a street, I suspicioned, for I cud hear people passin' an' talkin'. But I knew well I was far from home.  […]
